analytic.title: Chemical diffusion in melts on the CaMgSi206-CaA12Si208 join under high pressures

div.p: This study was designed to obtain data on the rates of chemical diffusion between melt couples of diopside to DidOAneO compositian and to determine changes in diffusion rates with temperature and pressure. Chemical diffusion in melts along the join diopside-anorthite can be described as binary (i.e., compositions remain on the join in the diffusion zone) up to a difference of 20 w-t?& between melt couple compositions. For larger concentration differences, mu~ticompo~ent diffusion matrices should be calculated. The diagonal elements of these matrices are similar to the effective binary diffusion coefficients determined from the binary diffusion equation, but the o&diagonal terms are of the same order of magnitude and cannot be neglected. Pressures up to 20 kbars do not change the diffusion coefficients significantly, although a diffusivity maximum may exist near 10 kbars. Activation energies for MgO and A1203 diffusion are consistent with a mechanism of individual ionic species diffusing through the melt.

THE APPLICATION OF KINETICS in geochemistry is generating a need for experiments designed to determine important kinetic parameters. Kinetic data for chemical diffusion are sparse in systems of geologic interest, and theories of reaction mechanisms have just begun to be generated for geochemical reactions. Movement is now underway toward understanding the kinetics of geochemical reactions as well as their thermodynamics. Since Bowen's early experiments ( BOWEN, 192 1 ), it has been recognized that rates and mechanisms of geochemicaf processes are important for understanding the time evolution of rocks, However, until recently, experimental. work has primarily focused on thermodynamics of geochemical systems, so the kinetic data base is not well developed. This investigation was designed to collect basic data on chemical diffusion in geochemically relevant melts and to study the mechanisms of diffusive transport for these melts.

The motivation for studying chemical diffusion in melts is that movement of ions across a concentration gradient is an important process in crystal growth, trace element partitioning, and maintenance of local equilibrium in partially molten systems ( HOFMANN, 1980 ). Chemical diffusion is not equivalent to tracer diffusion, which has been extensively studied in materials science and metallurgy, so data is needed for geochemical applications. The work of LASAGA ( 1982) and MUNCILL andLASAGA ( 1387, 1988) has been directed toward developing an integrated theory of diffusion and crystal growth in simple systems on the plagioclase liquidus; this study is a first step into the kinetics of diffusion in systems with diopside on the liquidus.

compositions along the diops~de-a~o~hite join (especially near the eutectic) were chosen because they approximate a simplified basaltic melt for our experimental purposes. Viscosities and SiO, cantents in diopside-anorthite eutectic melts are similar to basalts (KUSHIRO, 1980(KUSHIRO, , 1986;;SCARFE, 1973;SCARFE et al., 1983), so the diffusive behaviors should be comparable. Simple com~sitions are also preferred because natural rocks have so many components that accurate dif-fusion coefficients for coupled, multi-comp#~ent diffusion are difficult to calculate given the precision of microprobe analysis (the order of the diffusion coefficient matrix is proportional to (n -1 )2 where y1 is the number of independently diffusing components in the system). Further, the samples do not contain Fe which is absorbed into Pt capsules or Na which may be volatilized during the experiment or microprobe analysis. Of course, it is desirable to run experiments on more complex melt compositions to approximate natural systems, but finding reliable diffusion coefficients for the simple diopside-anorthite system is a reasonable first step before attempting to solve complex, multi-component diffusion equations involving nine or more diffusing components.

Other investigators ( KUWIRO, 1983; WATSON, 198 1) have noted significant pressure effects on cation diffusivities id melts. Network-forming ions in silicic melts exhibit anomalous increases in diffusion coe&cients with pressure, while network-m~ifying cation diffusion coefficients decrease with increasing pressure. The composition dependence of these trends must be understood in order to relate diffusion to melt structure. High-pressure experiments on chemical diffusion should help illuminate this relationship between structure and dynamics and constrain chemical diffusion in magmas within the Earth.

div.head: EXPERIMENTAL
div.p: Glasses were synthesized from spectroscopic grade oxide and CaCOj powders which were mixed for 15 min under ethanol in an automated mortar and pestle. Decarbonation of CaCO? was accomplished by heating the mixture at 900°C for over 4 h. Fusion of the samples took place at temperatures approximately 50°C above the liquidus for each composition ( 1350 to 1450°C) in a 1 atm F't-wound furnace. The melts were subsequently quenched in water. All glasses were pulverized, ground, and remelted to insure homogeneity. The glasses were crystal-free under the optical microscope and homogeneous within the precision of electron microprobe analysis.
Diffusion experiments were ;un in a %-inch solid-media pistoncylinder apparatus (Bout and ENGLAND, 1960) with diffusion couples contained with Pt capsules of 3 mm diameter and 6 mm length.

Crushed glasses were loaded into Pt capsules and precompacted to give a flat boundary between the two compositions. The original interface of the diffusion couple was determined by marking this surface with Pt black and with Boltzmann-Matano analysis of the diffusion profiles. Cross-checking between these two methods allows the center of the diffusion zone to be located within + 100 pm. Experimental run times varied between 0 and 30 min at 1500 to 1650°C (?S°C) measured with a Pt-Pt90RhlO thermocouple uncorrected for pressure. The diffusion experiments were performed in a solid-media piston-cylinder with 2 to 20 kbars (+ 1 kbar) confining pressure (-7% friction). Large relative pressure uncertainties (*SO%) exist therefore in the 2 kbar experiments. However, internally heated pressure vessels were not used because of the high temperatures necessary to melt these compositions. Uncertainty in the low-pressure experiments do not significantly affect the results or conclusions of this paper. Experiments performed in 1 atm furnaces and quenched in water often show the effects of physical mixing that occurs when air bubbles form in the sample and move to escape. Mixing may also occur when the molten sample is moved from the furnace to the quench cup, since any shaking in these low viscosity melts may easily mix the ends ofthe couple. The in situ quench (quench rate = 75"C/ set) in the piston-cylinder eliminates these effects, and large compositional deviations in the high-pressure diffusion profiles were not observed (Fig. 1) . Chemical analyses were performed on the MAC-automated electron microprobe at the Geophysical Laboratory. Point traverses of 100 to 200 points were made along the diffusion couple for 2 to 4 mm. All points with total percentages deviating more than f2 percentage points from 100% were rejected.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: From the MgO and Al203 concentration profiles in Fig. 5, the assumption of simple binary effusion in this system appears to be justified. The calculated curve fits the data for both elements through the diffusion zone and no "uphill" diffusion is observed. Diffusion coefficients for MgO and A&O3 also are nearly equivalent within experimental error, which is required if simple binary diffusion occurs for these com~sitions.

To check the stoichiomet~ of the diffusion zone, one of the components (diopside or anorthite) is subtracted from the compositions measured along the diffusion gradient. If diffusion can be described by exchange of stoichiometric amounts of CaMgSizOs and CaAl$izOs then the remainder of the oxide components should stay on a stoichiometric ratio of the component which was not subtracted. For example, after dete~ining the ano~hite component of a point in the diffusion zone from the A&O3 concentration, the ratio of Ga/Mg should equal 1 .O and for Si/Mg it should equal 2.0. Similarly, the diopside content may be found from the MgO content, and the remaining composition should have anorthite ratios of Ca/Al = 0.5 and Si/Al = 1 .O. Figure 6 shows that the compositions remain on stoichiomet~ at each end of the couple and in the diffusion zone. Simple binary diffusion may be applied in this case.

Diffusivity changes with pressure are negligible up to 20 kbars, which gives an activation volume ( AV,) of approximately zero over this pressure range. The implication from this data is that the melt is not closing the holes which allow ionic migration in the structure. If large, complex ionic species were moving through the melt as stable units, one would expect pressures of 20 kbars to significantly hinder diffusion. Thus, temperature and pressure effects on the rate of diffusion in diopside-anorthite melts both indicate that individual ions are the species involved in the chemical diffusion mechanism.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Chemical diffusion in the diopside-anorthite system may be described by the simple binary diffusion approximation if the concentration gradient of each component is less than 20 wt%. Effective binary diffusion coefficients decrease from approximately 3 X 10e6 in a Di-DisoAnzo couple to 1 X 10m6 cm*/sec in Di60An40-Di40An60 couple, indicating that diffusion is concentration dependent within this system. For systems with large concentration differences, multicomponent diffusion should be invoked and the entire (n -1 )2 diffusion matrix solved. Off-diagonal terms are relatively high in these diffusion matrices so there is a strong cation diffusion interdependence in these melts. Errors in determining D are also very large due to analytical imprecision and experimental startup times.

Activation energies of diffusion are similar to bond energies, which is consistent with a diffusion mechanism based on the movement of individual ions through the melt rather than large anionic complexes or polymer chains.

Pressure effects on the diopside-anorthite melt diffusion coefficients are negligible up to 20 kbars. Any decrease in diffusivity caused by higher pressures is likely to be more than offset by higher temperatures encountered at lower depths.

Piston-cylinder experiments are useful for studying chemical diffusion even at low pressures to alleviate any problems of physical mixing during the quench stage of the experiment. Melts with low viscosities will physically mix very readily with the escape of air bubbles or movement while quenching the sample. The in situ quench of the piston-cylinder apparatus is more reliable for maintaining the integrity of the experiment than the usual drop quench method employed in 1 atm furnaces.

Analysis of chemical diffusion in silicate melts is critical for understanding processes such as crystal growth from the atomistic perspective. Combining diffusion experiments with spectroscopic data on melt structures and computer simulations of melts ( KUBICKI and LASAGA, 1989) will allow us to understand the connections between structure and dynamics in silicate melts. With this achieved, we will be one step closer to an integrated theory of crystal growth in silicate melts.
